thread.title: Is your kid’s headache actually a STROKE? The pain is a ‘common sign in young victims,’ doctors warn
thread.title_full: Is your kid’s headache actually a STROKE? The pain is a ‘common sign in young victims,’ doctors warn

author: adowney
title: Is your kid’s headache actually a STROKE? The pain is a ‘common sign in young victims,’ doctors warn

organizations.name: american stroke association’s international stroke conference

text:
Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window) Comments YOUR child’s headache could be a sign they’re suffering stroke and should be “considered a possible diagnosis”, experts have warned. 
Kids are far more likely to complain of a headache when suffering a stroke, their new findings have shown. Alamy 2 Researchers examined more than 300 children and found that in almost half of stroke cases a headache was reported 
This prompted doctors to examine how frequently headache pain occurs in childhood stroke and whether headache pain is related to the reason of the stroke. 
Dr Lori Billinghurst, the study’s lead author and assistant professor of neurology at the University of Pennsylvania, said: “Stroke should be considered as a possible diagnosis in any child with a headache and additional symptoms of weakness or numbness – in the face, arm, or leg – or changes in walking, talking, or vision. 
“Urgent brain imaging may be required to distinguish a migraine with aura from a stroke.” 
Researchers looked at whether headache was noted at the onset of clot-caused stroke in 355 children. 
They found that in six per cent of cases in kids under three, and 46 per cent of cases of children older than three a headache was reported. 
It is possible that younger brains have blood vessels that are more easily distended and more likely to activate pain sensors that trigger headache Dr Lori Billinghurst University of Pennsylvania 
That is far higher than the estimated percentage of adults who experience a headache with an ischaemic stroke – one caused by a blood clot in the brain, the researchers said. 
The findings were presented at the American Stroke Association’s International Stroke Conference this week. 
The researchers warned younger children may not be able to communicate the pain they are feeling before having the stroke. 
Abnormalities in blood vessel walls are the most common reason for stroke in children , but a headache did not distinguish between children with artery abnormalities and children with other stroke-causing problems. Act FAST - IF YOU SPOT ONE SIGN DIAL 999 
The Act FAST campaign asks people to learn the signs someone could be suffering a stroke. 
FAST stands for: 
– FACE … has the person’s face fallen on one side? Can they still smile? 
– ARMS … can they raise both their arms and keep them there? 
– SPEECH … is their speech slurred? 
– TIME … if you spot any single one of these signs it’s time to dial 999 straight away Getty Images 2 Abnormalities in blood vessel walls are the most common reason for stroke in children 
Dr Billinghurst said: “It is possible that younger brains have blood vessels that are more easily distended and more likely to activate pain sensors that trigger headache. 
“It is also possible that inflammation – a powerful activator of pain sensors – may be more important in the processes underlying stroke in children than in adults. 
“The study has already shown that inflammation plays a key role in the vascular injury pathway in children with stroke.

“We will be doing further work to see if there are differences in blood markers of inflammation in those with and without headache at time of stroke.” 
However, researchers warned doctors should not yet use the presence of a headache to determine the cause of a stroke. 
Dr Billinghurst added: “We would like to conduct a study of children who enter hospital emergency rooms with headache and suspected stroke to see whether there are characteristics of the headache or other neurologic symptoms that predict whether a stroke will be confirmed on imaging. 
“We would like to develop a predictive formula that can help physicians diagnose stroke more rapidly and enable earlier, perhaps life-saving, stroke treatments.”
